content:
Japanese short-grain rice is a different beast altogether! While it's a great choice for sushi and other Japanese dishes, it might not be the best fit for this particular Indian-inspired meal.

Japanese short-grain rice is typically stickier and clingier than Indian basmati rice, which can affect the texture and flavor of the dish. Basmati rice, on the other hand, is known for its long, slender grains and nutty flavor, which pairs well with the spices and seasonings commonly used in Indian cuisine.

If you want to stay true to the Indian flavor profile, I'd recommend using a traditional Indian basmati rice. However, if you're feeling adventurous and want to experiment with a fusion flavor, you could try using your Japanese short-grain rice and see how it turns out.

Keep in mind that the cooking time and method might vary depending on the type of rice you use, so be sure to adjust accordingly. Japanese short-grain rice typically requires a different water ratio and cooking time than basmati rice.

Ultimately, the choice is yours! If you do decide to use your Japanese short-grain rice, I'd love to hear how it turns out.
